user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of can_compress:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
can_compress (struct MHD_Connection *con)
{
  const char *ae;
  const char *de;

  ae = MHD_lookup_connection_value (con,
                                    MHD_HEADER_KIND,
                                    MHD_HTTP_HEADER_ACCEPT_ENCODING);
  if (NULL == ae)
    return MHD_NO;
  if (0 == strcmp (ae,
                   "*"))
    return MHD_YES;
  de = strstr (ae,
               "deflate");
  if (NULL == de)
    return MHD_NO;
  if (((de == ae) ||
       (de[-1] == ',') ||
       (de[-1] == ' ')) &&
      ((de[strlen ("deflate")] == '\0') ||
       (de[strlen ("deflate")] == ',') ||
       (de[strlen ("deflate")] == ';')))
    return MHD_YES;
  return MHD_NO;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function can_compress:
_MHD_EXTERN const char *
MHD_lookup_connection_value (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                             enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                             const char *key)
{
  const char *value;

  value = NULL;
  (void) MHD_lookup_connection_value_n (connection,
                                        kind,
                                        key,
                                        (NULL == key) ? 0 : strlen (key),
                                        &value,
                                        NULL);
  return value;
}
...
#define MHD_HTTP_HEADER_ACCEPT_ENCODING "Accept-Encoding"
...
struct MHD_Connection
...
enum MHD_Result
{
  /**
   * MHD result code for "NO".
   */
  MHD_NO = 0,

  /**
   * MHD result code for "YES".
   */
  MHD_YES = 1

}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No loops (for, while, do-while) appear in can_compress, so there are no controlling expressions that could be invariant in the sense targeted by MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3. All conditional tests in the function are runtime-dependent and therefore not invariant:

- if (NULL == ae) — depends on the return value of MHD_lookup_connection_value called at runtime.
- if (0 == strcmp (ae, "*")) — depends on the contents of ae (runtime string comparison).
- if (NULL == de) — depends on the result of strstr called with ae at runtime.
- the compound if that checks surrounding characters of de and de[strlen("deflate")] — depends on pointer de and the runtime contents of the string; strlen("deflate") is a function call here (not an integer constant expression) and the character checks depend on the runtime buffer contents.

Because none of these are invariant constant controlling expressions, and because there are no loop conditions to which the rule (and its exceptions) would apply, there are no code fragments that need investigation under Rule 14.3 in the provided code.
